commitResults.messageTitle: Rename Duke.java to Vecrosen.java and Add greeting
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot is named Duke and has Duke's greeting.

The chatbot needs to be distinguished from Duke.

Let's change the name to Vecrosen and replace the greetings.

Vecrosen does not do anything other than greet the user.
Vecrosen's text is difficult to differentiate from the user's.

Let's make the chatbot parrot the user and add 4 spaces before
anything Vecrosen's says.

Also, apparently the class name within the Vecrosen.java only got
refactored now? Visual Studio's being weird.

Vecrosen has no way of terminating naturally.

Let's allow the user to end the interaction by entering "bye".

Vecrosen is still lacking in functionality.

Let's add a function for Vecrosen to output a list of items.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add support for updating the list
commitResults.messageBody:
The list that Vecrosen provides is static.
The speak() function doesn't allow text to be added before custom
inputs without using string concatenation.

If the user's input is large, string concatenation would have a large
time complexity, even if the string we wish to add is short.

Let's add anything the user says to the list and update speak() to
accept a prefix which is printed before the text.

The items in the list cannot be modified after being added.

Let's add a boolean to each list item to represent whether it has been
completed, and update the output of "list" to show if it has.

The "done" variable has no functionality, it instead alternates
value on creation.

Let's instead allow users to manually mark tasks as done by
specifying the index of the desired task after the word "mark".

commitResults.messageTitle: Change implementation of tasks to being their own objects
commitResults.messageBody:
The list of tasks is stored as an arraylist of strings and an
arraylist of booleans.

As the functionality of tasks is expected to grow, it is better
to treat each task as an object moving forward.

Let's create a Task class and update the implementation to
utilize it.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add special input: "unmark X" and fix numbering bug
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks, once marked as complete, could not be unmarked.
The numbering started at 46 instead of having a period
added after the number.

Let's add the command unmark and fix the aforementioned bug.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add the ability to specify task types
commitResults.messageBody:
All non-special input is treated as a task, hence only one
kind of task exists.

Let's allow the user to specify the type of task with the first word.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add support for Deadlines and Events
commitResults.messageBody:
Deadlines and Events are just tasks with details appended to
the back of their descriptions.

Let's make subclasses of Task so that the details can be stored
in variables.

When Vecrosen receives input in an invalid format, it does
not inform the user of how to properly use the command.

Let's add explanations as to how to use each command.

Users have no way of deleting tasks once they have been added to the list,
they could only mark them as complete.

Let's add a delete function to allow users to delete tasks.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add testcase for automated text-UI testing
commitResults.messageBody:
Testing has to be done manually.

Let's add a testcase so that the supplied runtest files can be used.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix bugs with the greeting and testcase

commitResults.messageBody:
Scanner is initialized within the while(true) loop.

Hence, a new instance of Scanner is made on each loop.

Let's move Scanner out of the while loop.

(Also, fixed a typo)

The list ceases to exist when the user exits the program.

Let's record the user's list in a file named vecrosen.txt.

The data in vecrosen.txt is not accessed by the program, and is
not formatted to be read easily by a Scanner.

Let's modify the save format and add the ability to load the file's contents.

Deadlines are stored as strings rather than dates.

While this is more flexible in some cases, in other cases it looks lazy.

Let's add date recognition to the by field.

I'm not here to jostle with java's DateTimeFormatter object. I. Am. DONE.

Only the field "by" under deadlines detect dates.

Let's make date detection into its own class and implement it into Event.java.

Code is currently all run under a single program Vecrosen.java

Modularizing the code has benefits down the line.

Let's create a class called UI.
Let's add a new class Parser to handle parsing.

commitResults.messageTitle: Make savefile access its own class
commitResults.messageBody: Let's add a class called Storage to handle reading and writing to the savefile.

commitResults.messageTitle: Make the tasklist its own class
commitResults.messageBody: Let's make a class called TaskList which manages functions updating and reading the list.

commitResults.messageTitle: Move all files into a package named vecrosen
commitResults.messageBody:
The files are in the source root folder.

Let's create a package to store them.

Dividing them into smaller packages can wait.
Let's add testcases to make use of Gradle.

The program cannot be exported.

Let's update build.gradle to allow for .jar files to be created.
Let's also update Vecrosen to make the directory data if it doesn't yet exist.

Some functions have no Javadoc comments

Let's add Javadoc comments to the remaining functions

Bugfixes: Vecrosen.java now reads the user's input through Ui.java
Adjustment from 1-indexing to 0-indexing moved to TaskList.java

commitResults.messageTitle: Make code compliant with coding standard
commitResults.messageBody:
Code does not comply with coding standard

Let's make the necessary adjustments to make it so.

Users cannot filter the list.

Let's add a find function to allow users to narrow their list down by a keyword.

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/vecrosen/Parser.java

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/vecrosen/Parser.java
#	src/main/java/vecrosen/TaskList.java
#	src/main/java/vecrosen/Ui.java

There are suggestions on how to improve the code's formatting.

Let's implement them.

(and use Checkstyle while we're at it)

Vecrosen accepts inputs from console and prints to console.

Let's begin work on a dialog window.

Dialog window only shows a label

Let's make it work as if it were the console.

This has created a ton of style errors, but I am too fatigued and too overdue to fix it. So it's done.

Checkstyle issues were created over the course of the previous updates.
Checkstyle flags array initialization as distinct from line extension
and hence expects array initialization to use 4 spaces more
instead of 8.

Let's fix the issues flagged by checkstyle except for indentation
during array initialization and update checkstyle to expect lines
in array initialization to be indented 8 spaces more than the
parent.

What do you mean we didn't need to write full git commit
messages, do you know how long it takes to write these?

Introduction is commented out.

Let's uncomment it.

The project calls for an assert to be inserted into the code.

As I do not have the foresight to infer what meaningful asserts I could
include, let's add one assert function to satisfy the requirement.

Some methods have lines of code far exceeding 30 lines.

While we are unable to reduce it below 30, the number of lines can be
significantly reduced.

Thus, let's add layers of abstraction to reduce the number of lines in
these methods.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add readme explaining the lack of streams
commitResults.messageBody:
Streams is an optional task in the iP description.

Let's add a readme clarifying our lack of intent of doing it.
Add token assert
Shorten long methods
Add readme explaining the lack of streams

Vecrosen only supports remembering tasks

Let's prepare to add a new type of object for
Vecrosen to remember: Clients.

There is no way to view the list of clients,
nor save or load it.

Let's make the program read/write to a separate savefile
to obtain the list of clients
Let's make the "list" command show the list of clients.

There is no way to edit the list of clients via the app.

Let's implement the command "client" to allow users to add
clients into the list.
